content: Because CHAMPUS is not a party to this appeal we do not reach point one; as to point two we reverse.
We affirm on all issues raised in the appeal and the cross-appeal.
For the reasons that follow, we affirm.
. We affirm.
We reverse and remand for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.
We affirm.
Based on the statutory authority for inmate release programs at local jails and our holding in State v. Guillen, 2001-NMCA-079,  11, 130 N.M. 803, 32 P.3d 812, we affirm.
For these reasons, we affirm the opinion of the Court of Appeals.
For the reasons set forth below, we reject Defendant's contentions and affirm the judgment of the trial court.

We reverse the district court grant of summary judgment in favor of Eaton, Martinez & Hart, P.C. and grant summary judgment in favor of University Hospital. We affirm the district court decision in favor of Memorial Hospital in the consolidated case of Crawford v. Scully.
We affirm the Court of Appeals.
For the reasons discussed herein, we reverse and remand for further proceedings.
We affirm.
Because the affidavit in support of the search warrant established probable cause, we affirm.
In an issue of first impression in New Mexico, we hold that the Constitution grants the state no such right, and we reverse.
We affirm and remand, directing the district court to enter an amended judgment and sentence vacating the reckless driving conviction.
We affirm.
Because we determine that the State failed to bring Defendant to trial within six months of the date the mandate was filed with the district court, we reverse.

Because we do not agree that the statutory scheme violated Defendant's rights, is void for vagueness, or that the statute criminalizes the exercise of his Fourth Amendment rights, we affirm his convictions.
We affirm.
We affirm.
We reverse and hold that the ordinance does not violate the Separation of Powers Clause of the New Mexico Constitution.
For the reasons discussed herein, we affirm.
We affirm.
We therefore reverse the trial court's order refusing to suppress marijuana subsequently seized during a search of Defendant's ear.
We affirm Defendant's convictions and reverse with regard to his sentence.
Consequently, we reverse.

Deciding that the record does not support a finding either that she did or that she waived such notice, we reverse the order of permanent guardianship and remand to the district court for it to decide after an evidentiary hearing whether it should continue the temporary guardianship or issue a permanent guardianship consistent with the best interests of the child.
We reverse and remand.
We affirm the judgment of the trial court as to Plaintiffs' points one through five, as well as its denial of costs.
On interlocutory appeal, we affirm and remand to the district court for prosecution of the felony indictment
We affirm the verdict and the award of prejudgment interest on the compensatory damages portion of the award.

We reverse the grant of partial summary judgment and remand the case to the district court for further proceedings on these claims. We affirm the district court's refusal to instruct the jury on punitive damages.
This Court declines to abate this ease ab initio, upholding the conviction and concluding that no error occurred warranting relief.
We hold that the trial court imposed an unnecessary requirement of "reasonableness" to issue an injunction in the circumstances of this case and reverse.
We reverse and remand to the district court with instructions to enter a judgment granting Allianz's motion to compel arbitration.
We affirm.
We affirm.
We affirm the district court's dismissal of Defendant's appeal from his magistrate court convictions.
Based on the particular facts of this case, we affirm the trial court's approval of the settlement.

We affirm the district court's dismissal for failure to pursue the remedies set forth in the State Personnel Act. We also affirm the district court's decision to dismiss claims of retaliatory discharge and claims arising under the state constitution.
We are unpersuaded by Plaintiffs arguments and affirm the district court's order granting summary judgment.
We affirm.
We reverse and remand for further proceedings in district court.
We affirm.
Accordingly, we reverse and remand this case to state district court to determine whether Navajo law applies to Belone's wrongful repossession counterclaim.

For the reasons that follow, we affirm Defendant's conviction for DWI from the first trial in this ease. With regard to the remainder of Defendant's convictions following the third trial, we reverse and remand for a new trial.

Concluding, for the purposes of qualified immunity, that these Defendants have not violated Plaintiffs right to due process, we reverse the order of the trial court denying summary judgment as to these individually named Defendants.
We reverse.
For the reasons discussed herein, we hold that Plaintiffs appeal was untimely and dismiss the appeal.
For the reasons discussed herein, we affirm.
Accordingly, we affirm the Court of Appeals, which had affirmed Baca's conviction in an unpublished decision.

We hold that the record is not sufficient to support the trial court's decision, and we therefore reverse the trial court's order granting Halliburton's motion to compel arbitration. We remand for reconsideration of Halliburton's motion.
We hold that attempt to commit a violation of the WQA is a lesser included offense in this instance, and we remand to the trial court for adjudication of guilt on attempt and resentencing.
The Court of Appeals having decided differently, we now reverse and affirm the convictions below.
We reverse the conviction and remand for a new trial.
. We reverse the Court of Appeals' decision and affirm the district court's order.
We therefore remand for entry of a new award, requiring Employer to bear one hundred percent of Worker's attorney's fees.
We thus affirm the judgment and disposition, as well as the trial court's denial of Student's motion to suppress the weapon discovered in the search.
The May 24, 2001 judgment is vacated and this case is remanded with instructions to reinstate the August 3, 1999 judgment. Plaintiffs cross-appeal is dismissed.
We affirm Gonzales' conviction for felony DWI. We reverse his sentence and remand for resentencing.
Applying the guidelines we adopt herein, we deny Defendant's application for appeal.
We affirm.
Under the specific facts of this case, we answer both questions in the affirmative.
We agree and reverse and remand to the district court for a de novo appeal.
We agree and reverse.
We reverse Defendant's conviction for abuse of a child and remand for re-sentencing. We affirm his conviction for criminal sexual penetration, and affirm the trial court in all other respects.

We conclude that the regulation discriminates against Plaintiffs on the basis of their disabilities in violation of Title II of the ADA, and affirm the Order invalidating the HSD regulation which imposed a twelve-month maximum period of eligibility for disabled adults receiving benefits under the General Assistance Program.

Because we are not persuaded that the legislature intended multiple punishments for the same offense or that the legislature intended to pumsh every CSP that resulted from force and restraint as a second-degree felony, we remand this case to the trial court with instructions to vacate Defendant's conviction and sentence for kidnapping and CSP II in the commission of a kidnapping.
We affirm.
For the reasons discussed below, we reverse the trial court's decision rejecting the self-defense instruction and remand for a new trial.
Determining that Worker had no such right, we reverse the district court and affirm the Board's final order.
Thus, we reverse the Court of Appeals and affirm the trial court's grant of summary judgment.
We reject Duran's arguments and, for the reasons stated below, we affirm.
The summary judgment in favor of Dr. Nelson is affirmed.
We disagree and reverse the district court.
We reverse the Court of Appeals and the judgment in favor of Jackson.
We affirm the convictions.

We reverse and remand because we reject Husband's arguments that: (1) he was entitled in the proceedings below to show that Oklahoma did not have personal jurisdiction over him; and (2) New Mexico did not have to give full faith and credit to the Oklahoma judgment Wife was seeking to file because Oklahoma did not give full, faith and credit to an earlier New Mexico judgment.
We affirm.
We conclude that Section 30-7-16 does not permit a felon in possession conviction under these circumstances and affirm the district court's granting of Defendant's motion to dismiss.

We affirm the district court's decision to impute income based upon Father's underemployment and failure to make a good faith effort to become fully employed. We reverse the amount of the income imputation for lack of evidence and remand for the district court to determine Father's earning capacity for purposes of imputed income.
We affirm.
For the reasons discussed below, we affirm the judgment with respect to Plaintiffs claims against Charter for negligent misrepresentation and negligent selection and supervision of McGregor.
We disagree with Taxpayer's arguments and affirm.
We affirm.
We conclude that Cooper's remarks to the hostage negotiators were voluntary and affirm his felony murder conviction.
We vacate the district court's order denying De fendant's motion to dismiss and remand for further proceedings on the issue of manifest necessity.
Not persuaded by the memorandum, we affirm.

Because the WCJ found the amount of hours expended by counsel to be reasonable and necessary and because the particular communication here did not appear improper, we cannot affirm the reduction in attorney fees in this case. Therefore, we remand to the WCJ to reconsider the award of attorney fees.

We further hold that the State violated Defendant's right to a speedy trial, and we therefore reverse his convictions and remand for the district court to enter an order dismissing the charges against Defendant.
We agree and affirm.
Finding that the evidence of the currency was properly suppressed, we affirm.

We hold that the present appeal is premature and that unless and until the district court finally disposes of the pending claim for damages, or certifies the appeal pursuant to Rule 1-054(C)(1) NMRA 1996, there is no final order to support appellate jurisdiction in this Court.
We hold that NORA is hable only for its own 60% fault, but we affirm on all other grounds.
A s to Defendant's first three arguments, we affirm the trial court.
We affirm as to the Village, but in doing so, we clarify the reach and meaning of the judgment in favor of the Village.
Because we determine that the first and second issues raised on appeal are moot and Mother's constitutional challenge to the Protection Act is without merit, we affirm.
We affirm.
We hold that it does and reverse the decision of the district court.
We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.
Accordingly, we reverse.
We affirm.
We affirm.
We affirm the trial court's denial of Defendants' motions.
We affirm.

We uphold the district court's denial of the motion to suppress, but reverse Defendant's sentence because the district court applied the habitual offender statute, NMSA 1978,  31-18-17(B) (1993), to a conditional discharge granted under NMSA 1978,  30-31-28(A) (1972) of the Controlled Substances Act.
We affirm.
B ecause we reverse the independent arbitrator's decision upholding the local school board's termination of Kibbe on this ground, we do not reach Kibbe's arguments concerning the COEA.
We affirm his convictions for felony murder and conspiracy, vacate his conviction for shooting at a dwelling, and remand for resentencing.
Because there is insufficient evidence in the record to support a finding of fraud on Varbel's part, we reverse.
We reverse on the first issue and affirm on the second.
We therefore reverse the award of attorney fees.
We vacate the district court order affirming the award and remand the case to a new panel of arbitrators to evaluate the merits of the original claim.
Unpersuaded by Design Professionals' arguments, we affirm.
We reverse and remand for further proceedings.

Today, we reverse only the portion of the Court of Appeals' decision that discusses statements against penal interest because it applied the incorrect standard of review. Accordingly, we remand to the district court as ordered by the Court of Appeals.
We affirm.
We affirm the spoliation sanction and reverse on the issue of third-party liability.
We therefore deny the petition for the writ and lift the stay of Commission business.
We hold that the district court erred, and we reverse.
We determine that the jury instructions on aggravated battery with a deadly weapon were improper and we therefore reverse and remand on that issue only

We affirm the trial court's rulings that the NMMFRA does not create a common-law third-party beneficiary relationship between an injured person and the tortfeasor's liability insurer, and that New Mexico does not recognize a common-law cause of action by an injured third party against the tortfeasor's liability insurer for bad faith refusal to settle.
We reverse and remand for further proceedings on the exemption issue.
We affirm.
Thus, we affirm the trial court's grant of summary judgment for Defendants.
Because the record is devoid of substantial evidence supporting-the order, we vacate the order and remand to the Commission.
Accordingly, we affirm the judgment terminating Father's parental rights.
We determine that it was and reverse.
We affirm the district court's decision to that effect, and therefore we do not address the court's alternative ground for denying coverage.
We affirm the summary judgment in favor of H.C. and reverse the summary judgment in favor of John
We are unpersuaded that the trial court abused its discretion and therefore affirm.

We order that the finding of Father's contempt be stricken as surplusage and reverse those provisions of the district court's order that included recreational expenses in the calculation of child support and that directed the transfer of the case to Tennessee. We affirm on all other grounds.
The district court ruled in the affirmative, and for the following reasons, we agree.

Concluding that Defendant was convicted of CSCM and attempted CSPM based on unitary conduct and that the legislature has not clearly expressed an intention for multiple punishments for unitary conduct that violates NMSA 1978, Section 30-9-11(0 (2001), and NMSA 1978, Section 30-9-13(A) (2001), we reverse and remand to the trial court with instructions to vacate Defendant's conviction and sentence for CSCM.
We determine that the WCJ incorrectly applied the law to the facts of this ease, and therefore reverse and remand.
We hold that the Children's Code preempts the Curfew and the Safe Teen Operation Program (STOP program), and thus affirm the district court.
We hold that Garrison P. controls under the circumstances of this case and, accordingly, reverse.

We reverse and remand for a new trial because there was fundamental error in the jury instructions. Because we reverse and remand on issues (1) and (2) relating to instructional error, we do not address the remaining issues raised.
We reverse and remand with instructions for the trial court to set a date for a hearing on Vieira's claims.

Because the district court engaged in fact-finding functions and otherwise failed to follow the limited review of an appellate court, we reverse and remand with instructions to affirm the board's decision revoking the professional license.

We find it unnecessary, however, to decide whether for the purpose of appeal the date of the signing, or the date of the filing and recording of the order is controlling, for the reason that the appeal must be dismissed upon another ground, to-wit, that the appeal is not prosecuted from a final judgment.
For tfie reasons discussed below, we reverse the district court and lift the injunction
We now reverse.
We hold that Defendant was entitled to a jury trial in the district court and therefore reverse his conviction and remand for a new trial.
We affirm on all issues.
Accordingly, we affirm the result reached by the Court of Appeals, on different grounds, and we remand to the district court for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.
As a result, we reverse the district court and affirm the annexation proceedings of the Commission.
For the reasons that follow, we affirm.
Holding that the duty to compensate still exists, we reverse the district court's order granting summary judgment.
Deciding that Defendant's house arrest should not be deemed official confinement under NMSA 1978, Section 31-20-12 (Repl.Pamp.1994), we affirm.
We affirm.
Thus, we affirm the district court's entry of summary judgment for the homeowner.
Defendant's motion is denied.
We dismiss the appeal as premature because it does not originate from a final order.
We affirm the orders of the district court affirming these dismissals.
We accepted certification and now reverse the district court's order denying Defendant's double jeopardy claim.
We affirm.
We affirm the district court

We affirm the trial court's order granting summary judgment for Defendants; we reverse the trial court's supplemental order imposing costs against Defendants, and remand for further proceedings involving the assessment of costs.
We affirm the court's arrearages award and denial of attorney fees. We reverse the court's denial of interest.
We affirm.
We hold the receipts are subject to tax and affirm the district court.

We therefore affirm the trial court's order directing that the mortgage held by Mortgagee was satisfied and that the transcript of judgment held by Judgment Creditor was subject to the exemption and should be released.
We hold that Defendant has the right to appeal from the order permitting a new trial, but we affirm the order because Defendant was not acquitted of the CSP charge.
We reverse the trial court's order dismissing the petition.
Finding no error below, we affirm the district court's order.
Reversed and remanded.
We affirm the trial court in both respects.
We therefore affirm the Workers' Compensation Judge (WCJ).
We reverse and remand to the trial court to conduct a new hearing pursuant to Section 31-9-1.
We affirm.
We reverse Defendant's conviction and remand for a new trial.
We review whether Petitioners have stated a claim of public nuisance pursuant to NMSA 1978, Section 30-8-l(B) (Repl.Pamp.1994), and affirm.
We agree that the State failed to prove exigent circumstances and reverse the denial of Defendant's motion to suppress.
We therefore reverse the grant of summary judgment in Defendants' favor.
Without deciding whether either of those two issues, standing alone, gave rise to reversible error, we determine that, together, they formed the basis for cumulative error requiring reversal.
Finding that substantial evidence supports the district court's conelusion that the underlying lawsuit was brought without the necessary probable cause, we affirm the judgment.
Accordingly, we affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.
We hold that the Department properly considered the applicable regulatory requirements, reject the other claims, and affirm.
We affirm.
We therefore affirm the dismissal of Plaintiffs complaint.
We agree with Defendant that the EBT card is not a credit card under Section 30-16-33 and therefore reverse.
We note jurisdiction under SCRA 1986, 12-102(A)(2) (Repl.Pamp.1992) (directing to Supreme Court appeals from district courts in which sentence of life imprisonment has been imposed), and affirm.
We reverse the trial court's decision to revoke Child's probation:

For the most part, we affirm the tidal court's decision to adopt a portion of the special master's report, and we also affirm the court's decision not to adopt that portion of the report relating to the computation of Father's income
Not persuaded, we affirm.
We therefore deny EPEC's motion to permit further briefing, quash our order accepting certification, and now decline to accept certification.
We affirm.
We affirm the trial court's denial of the permanent injunction.
We reverse the orders of the trial court denying Defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment.

We reverse and remand for a new trial on the grounds that Uniform Jury Instruction (UJI), NMUJI 1996, 14-2228, fails to instruct the jury on all the essential elements of the crime of escape from the inmate-release program.
We affirm the district court and remand for a fair hearing.
Deciding that the court erred in this respect, we reverse.
We affirm.
Because TPL met its burden to establish that it provided services to an out-of-state buyer that neither made initial use nor took delivery of its product of service in New Mexico, we reverse

Because this process is properly rooted in a factual determination and the district court's decision did not consider factors beyond the "current state of the law," at the time it dismissed the loss of consortium claims, we reverse the district court's granting of the City of Gallup's motion to dismiss and remand for proceedings consistent with this opinion.
We reverse and grant summary judgment based on that exclusion.
We therefore reverse the trial court's denial of Defendant's motion to suppress under the first and second issues.
Consequently, we reverse.
We also agree, though for different reasons, and we therefore affirm the judgment of the district court and the Court of Appeals.
Thus, we affirm.
We agree and reverse and remand to the district court for entry of an amended judgment.
We reverse the presentenee credit allowed by the trial court and affirm as to suspension of Defendant's sentence conditioned upon attendance at the treatment facility.
We granted the petition, and for the reasons set forth below, we reverse.

Both parties have responded to the proposed disposition and, having considered their arguments, we reverse the order denying the motion to dismiss and remand to the district court for reconsideration in light of the standards enunciated below.
For the reasons discussed below, we affirm Defendant's convictions and sentence.
We reverse.
We affirm the judgment of the trial court.

We reverse because Child did not demonstrate, as part of his burden below, that he was not predisposed to sell the cocaine when he had the burden to do so and because objective entrapment does not apply to this case.

We also reverse the Court of Appeals' holding that the district court failed to fully evaluate the merits of the motion and we affirm the district court's denial of plaintiffs' Rule 1-060(B)(6) motion.
On that ruling, we reverse.
We reverse.
We reverse the trial court's ruling and remand for a new trial.
We affirm in part and reverse in part.
We reverse and remand for further proceedings.
We affirm the ruling of the trial court.

We affirm the trial court and hold that, under the particular facts of this case, the rejection form signed by Genara Vigil was valid and Plaintiffs are not entitled to have uninsured motorists coverage read into their policy.
We affirm and remand.
Because the arbitrator failed to use the correct standard of review, we remand for a new arbitration.
We therefore reverse in part and affirm in part.
We affirm the orders of the WCJ.
We reverse the trial court's order suppressing the evidence.
Thus, we affirm.

Concluding that the Bassetts failed to successfully sever the water rights from the land prior to sale of the property, and concluding that adverse possession of water rights cannot occur in New Mexico, we reverse and remand for trial on the merits on Turner's action to quiet title, and for trial on the merits of Turner's remaining claims for restitution and declaratory judgment.

We affirm the trial court's decision because the Defendants' construction of the statute is valid and Carlsbad abandoned any right to oppose enforcement of valid rules, regulations, and policies when it settled prior litigation with the State Board.FACTSTraining and Experience Index{2} In 1969, the State Legislature enacted the New Mexico State Equalization Guarantee Distribution.
Because Defendants failed to timely appeal the order, and instead chose to postpone an appeal until after an arbitration award was rendered against them, we dismiss their appeal.
Unpersuaded by the State's arguments, we affirm.
For the reasons discussed herein, we affirm in part and reverse in part.
We affirm.
We affirm.
We therefore affirm the trial court's order of dismissal.
We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.
We conclude as a matter of first impression that the district court is the proper forum and reverse the compensation order of the WCJ.
We hold in Augustin M. that Child does not have an immediate right to appeal and we therefore dismiss the appeal.

We therefore reverse Defendant's sentence under the Act.Commencement of Trial Under Rule 5-60U{2} After Defendant was convicted of forgery, the State filed a supplemental information to enhance Defendant's sentence under the Act. Section 31-18-17.
For the following reasons, we affirm.
Therefore, we reverse the order dismissing the claim, and we remand for further proceedings on the merits of the claim.
On interlocutory appeal from that ruling, we reverse and remand for trial without a jury.
We reverse the revocation of Defendant's probation holding that the judgment is not in effect during the pendency of Defendant's appeal.
We conclude that there was fundamental error in the jury instruction and reverse and remand for a new trial on Defendant's conviction for intimidating a witness.
We hold that the Act does not afford Defendant immunity, and we reverse the district court's order to the contrary and remand for further proceedings.
We affirm in part and reverse in part.
For the reasons stated below, we affirm.
We agree with the court below and affirm its denial of Defendant's motion to suppress.
We vacate the district court's order and reverse and remand for entry of an order requiring the Director to submit Petitioner's complete application to a panel.
We hold that there are genuine issues of material fact concerning what occurred the night of the shooting and reverse the order granting summary judgment for Officer LaCuesta.

We affirm the trial court on all issues except the sentencing of Defendant for both felony murder and intentional child abuse resulting in death; therefore, we need not address the issue of whether cumulative error deprived Defendant of a fair trial.

We affirm the trial court's decree of foreclosure, including interest accrued, to be paid from the foreclosure sale proceeds. However, we reverse, in part, because of restrictions imposed by the court on the builder's ability to execute upon its judgment and to obtain a deficiency judgment for its damages against the buyer.

We conclude that the district court abused its discretion by reducing Chrysler's total costs and remand for a new evidentiary hearing on this issue consistent with this opinion, but we affirm the district court's decision regarding computer-assisted legal research.
Therefore, we dismiss the appeal as premature.
We affirm the trial court's decision in both the direct and cross-appeal.
We affirm.
Cunningham's conviction is therefore affirmed

We granted application for interlocutory appeal and now hold that the trial court neither abused its discretion in refusing to reinstate the original plea nor erred in refusing to dismiss the death-penalty proceedings.
We reverse the summary judgment and remand for further proceedings
We therefore reverse the district court on that issue and remand for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.

For the reasons discussed below, we reverse the decision of the WCA as it relates to the reimbursement award and imposition of attorney's fees, and remand the matter for further proceedings. We affirm the WCA's determination regarding Chavez' wage upon returning to work.
Pursuant to NMSA 1978,  62-11-5 (1982), under which this Court may affirm or annul an action by the Commission, we are asked to annul and vacate the order of the Commission.
We therefore reverse and remand for a new trial.
Taxpayer appeals, and be cause we agree with the hearing officer on all points, we affirm.
We agree with Employer that there is no compelling reason to depart from the plain, unambiguous language of the statute, and reverse.
We reverse and remand for reinstatement of the charge.
Not persuaded by Defendant's arguments, we affirm on all issues.
We affirm.
For the reasons set out below, we affirm the amended judgment and sentence.
We hold that as a matter of law Defendant is not a public employee; therefore, we reverse his conviction for misappropriating public assistance.
Since the district court did not lack jurisdiction to act upon the State's petition, we reverse the Court of Appeals.
Therefore, we vacate the Commission's order.

We conclude that sufficient evidence supports the first degree kidnapping conviction and that the kidnapping statute passes constitutional muster. We also hold that double jeopardy has been violated and remand to vacate the enticement conviction and one of the attempted CSCM convictions.
Therefore, we affirm.
We affirm and address the nature of the fiduciary duties shareholders and directors of close corporations owe to each other.
We affirm in part and reverse in part the district court's grant of summary judgment in Defendant's favor on the defamation counts, and reverse as to the tortious interference with contract count.

We take this opportunity to affirm and expand our holding in Eaton, to address somewhat different arguments raised in this case, and to clarify what constitutes disbursement of insurance policy proceeds triggering the commencement of the period by which the statute of limitations is measured.

We vacate the order granting Landfill's application and remand to the Secretary for de novo review of Landfill's application after publication of notice substantially complying with Subsection 74-9-22(0).
For the foregoing reasons, we reverse the trial court's February 16, 1996, order awarding a share of Husband's military retirement pay to Wife.
We hold that Reed is not a fugitive from justice and affirm the writ of habeas corpus.
Accordingly, we affirm.
We affirm in part and reverse in part.
We affirm.
We therefore reverse and remand for the district court to vacate its order dismissing the petition and to enter an order severing the clause in question.

We affirm the district court, holding that, based upon the language of Section 42A-1-21 and the statute's history, the legislature intended to provide for a jury trial on the issues of public use and necessity.
We affirm the decision of the district court on alternative grounds recited in this opinion.
We reverse summary judgment on both claims and remand for further proceedings.

We granted the petition, and we now reverse and remand to the district court to conduct an appellate review of the Village proceedings, using the duly approved minutes of the Village meetings as the official transcript of those proceedings.
Accordingly, we affirm in part and dismiss the appeal in part.
For the reasons discussed herein, we affirm the district court's judgment and sentence.
The judgment of the Court of Appeals is affirmed in part and reversed in part.
For the reasons discussed herein, we affirm in part and reverse in part
We hold that PNM has no duty to the public to maintain streetlights, under the circumstances of this case, and therefore we affirm the trial court.
For the reasons discussed below, we affirm.
We therefore affirm.
The district court denied Inca relief and we now affirm.
We hold that the record before us is insufficient to support the search and therefore reverse.
We therefore affirm.
We agree with the hearing officer and affirm his decision for the reasons stated below.
We affirm.
We affirm the district court.
That date was almost a year earlier than any IRS notice of deficiency was issued; the statute of limitations had run, and we reverse the district court.
We affirm.
The judgment of the trial court based upon the jury verdict is hereby affirmed.
We affirm.

We affirm the Court of Appeals on the issue of whether the initial pat down was a valid protective search, though we base our holding on an objective standard instead of an analysis of whether the search was pretextual.
We affirm Defendant's convictions.
We therefore reverse the trial court's judgment.

Having given careful consideration to Worker's arguments, we conclude that the judge's award of scheduled injury benefits was correct, that Worker has not demonstrated that she meets the requirements for total disability, and that substantial evidence supports the judge's decision.
We hold that the patdown search that revealed methamphetamine in Defendant's sock was illegal',^reverse the denial of the motion to suppress, and remand for further proceedings.
We affirm.
The order granting Defendant's motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction is affirmed.
We therefore reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals and affirm the sentence imposed by the district court.
We also affirm the trial court's decision to increase Defendant's sentence for criminal sexual penetration because of aggravating circumstances.
We reverse the partial summary judgment and remand for further proceedings on the oral-contract claim. We affirm the judgment in favor of RRA and Rashkin (Defendants) on the written-contract claim.
We agree with the Court of Appeals' conclusion, although we modify its interpretation of a portion of the statute, and we affirm the Court of Appeals' order remanding this cause for a new trial.

We affirm Defendant's convictions for aggravated burglary, conspiracy to commit burglary, and larceny of a firearm. We reverse Defendant's conviction of larceny over $250 on the ground of double jeopardy.

For the reasons that follow, we affirm the trial court's denial of Prudential's motion for summary judgment, reverse the grant of partial summary judgment in favor of Plaintiffs, and remand for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.
Having carefully reviewed the State's arguments, and being unpersuaded, we reverse.
We reverse.
We agree with Petitioners and dismiss the appeal for lack of appellate jurisdiction.
We hold that the summary judgment motion should not have been granted, and therefore we reverse and remand the case to the trial court for hearing

We hold that the State's appeal was timely filed, and we reverse because the district court applied the wrong legal standard for evaluating a facially sufficient search warrant affidavit attacked as misleading. We remand for a new suppression hearing.
We agree that the protest was not timely and affirm.
We affirm Defendant's conviction.
We affirm the grant of summary judgment and the order denying GCM's motion for reconsideration.
Upon doing so we now affirm the decision of the district court.

We determine that instruction on the record is necessary, and for the reasons discussed herein we affirm the order of dismissal in State v. Ulibarri & Popplewell, No. 19,126, and reverse the order in State v. Montoya, No. 19,451.
We affirm.
We affirm the district court's confirmation of the arbitration award and remand the order awarding additional attorney's fees to be vacated by the district court.
We affirm.
Because we believe genuine issues of material fact preclude judgment as a matter of law, we reverse and remand.
We reverse because we conclude that the "general/specific rule" is inapplicable.
We affirm the conviction and sentence.
Finding reversible error, we reverse Defendant's conviction for felony murder and remand for a new trial.
We conclude that the clause is in violation of public policy, but we select a different remedy than the one selected by the Court of Appeals.
Accordingly, we reverse and remand for further proceedings.
We affirm.
We affirm Defendant's convictions.
Because neither party entered the UM Policy into the record before the district court dismissed this action, we are unable to decide this issue at this time.
We affirm.
We affirm.

Thus, we disavow the natural and probable consequence standard of accessory liability and affirm the intent requirement New Mexico has embodied in its uniform jury instructions for accessory liability.
We affirm.
We affirm.
Because we reverse as to the second issue, we need not decide the first issue raised by Defendant.
We affirm as to all issues except the directed verdict as to the loss of consortium claim, and the verdict of no negligence as to one of the Defendants.
We therefore remand the issue of sanctions. In other respects, we affirm.
We affirm on issues one and five and reverse on issue two.
We remand the case to the Board, ordering the Board to provide Mills with a reinstatement proceeding which complies with the requirements of due process.
We affirm as to the first two arguments and the payment of interest but reverse as to the payment of penalties.
Accordingly, we reverse.

We reverse the jury's award of nominal damages and punitive damages for fraudulent misrepresentation. We affirm the trial court's award of nominal damages and punitive damages for breach of fiduciary duty and its award of attorney's fees.
We therefore affirm the Court of Appeals.
We also affirm the award of attorney fees to Autos II as a sanction against Avlin for non-compliance with Rule 1-056(D), NMRA 1997.
Finding no error and finding sufficient evidence to support the convictions, we affirm

We affirm the Judgment appointing Father as personal representative of Kirsten's estate. We reverse the district court's determination that Father is the sole Section 41-2-3 beneficiary of the action for Kirsten's wrongful death. We affirm the district court's determination that Father has not been divested of his interest in any recovery for Kirsten's wrongful death.

We reverse the trial court and hold that the Legislature removed all discretion from the trial court in determining whether to impose consecutive or concurrent sentences on inmates for felonies committed during incarceration, and as such all sentences for inmate committed crimes are to be consecutive to the total of all combined sentences.
